newsitem.title: GERMANY: Buba rate decision key for German share outlook.
newsitem.headline: Buba rate decision key for German share outlook.

text.p: Short-term prospects for German shares hinge almost entirely on the outcome of the Bundesbank's council meeting on Thursday, dealers said Wednesday afternoon.
Dealers warned of a knee-jerk reaction downwards should the meeting fail to yield a cut in the securities repurchase rate, or repo, or a move to a variable repo.

In late trading Wednesday, the IBIS DAX index which tracks electronic trade was down 22.95 points at 2,539.17, undermined by a stronger-than expected Ifo business climate report which shook the market's faith that a repo cut was imminent.

The report showed the July Ifo index soared to 94.1 from 90.1 in June, sharply exceeding expectations and signalling a level of confidence about business prospects that might stall the Bundesbank from cutting rates.
Although a majority of economists said the report made a rate easing less likely, many dealers remained hopeful that a repo cut of five to 10 basis points was in the offing.
"The Ifo is of course a negative but if I had to flip a coin, I would still say a move is likely," said a Frankfurt dealer.
Should the Bundesbank decide against cutting the repo, the DAX risks a drop as low as 2,480 points over the coming days via a support around 2,510, one Duesseldorf dealer said.
"The market has been overbought for several weeks now and I think if we got back to those lower levels people would start to buy back in," the dealer said.

Dealers also warned that a small five-basis-point cut in the repo might not have a positive impact, and that the market would really prefer a move to a variable rate repo -- which few observers expect -- as this would leave more scope for further rate declines in the future.
Dealers said the fact that more investors returned to the market on Wednesday, when prices were falling, indicated that a downward trend was in place.
Trading had been lacklustre earlier in the week.

Among shares under pressure was utility Viag AG, which was down 9.35 marks at 560 marks in IBIS trade after reporting a 21 percent drop in its first-half pre-tax profit, which dealers said was at the low end of expectations.
Retail stocks also remained under pressure, which dealers suggested may be linked to the stalemate in talks to agree a wage and work hours deal to cope with liberalised shop hours.
The market overall will remain strongly vulnerable to the Bund market, always a strong leader for shares, and a major factor in their weakness on Wednesday, traders said.
"We've already seen Bunds fall through several supports today. Whatever they do on the Bundesbank, we are likely to follow," said a Frankfurt dealer.
